attachments.title: Benchmarking with @time @btime and subsequent runs return shorter execution time
attachments.text: I am using @time and @btime macros to determine how my function preforms on different number of threads. I am mostly interested not in specific time but relative values. Threads aside, I noticed that the more times I run tests the faster the function gets. Below with @time: julia> @time modeltest(mdl_init); 20.720889 seconds (214.16 M allocations: 7.629 GiB, 31.47% gc time) julia> @time modeltest(mdl_init); 2.384151 seconds (174.74 M allocations: 5.730 GiB, 55.80% gc time) julia> @time mode...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Benchmarking with @time @btime and subsequent runs return shorter execution time

messages.text:
You see this pattern all over the place in the Julia source, where you do a reduction over the arguments via multiple dispatch, something like:
```my_reduce(op::Function, a, b, c, rest...) = my_reduce(op, a, my_reduce(op, b, c, rest...))
my_reduce(op::Function, a, b) = op(a,b)
my_reduce(op::Function, a) = a```
I'm trying to write a similar  `my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, args...)`, I know I've seen it somewhere in the source too but can't quite remember. Can anyone remind me where there might be an example, or give hints how to do it? I think maybe you need two functions?

elements.text: You see this pattern all over the place in the Julia source, where you do a reduction over the arguments via multiple dispatch, something like:

my_reduce(op::Function, a, b, c, rest...) = my_reduce(op, a, my_reduce(op, b, c, rest...))
my_reduce(op::Function, a, b) = op(a,b)
my_reduce(op::Function, a) = a
I'm trying to write a similar
, I know I've seen it somewhere in the source too but can't quite remember. Can anyone remind me where there might be an example, or give hints how to do it? I think maybe you need two functions?

messages.text:
```my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a, b, c, rest...) = my_mapeduce(f, op, a, my_mapreduce(f, op, b, c, rest...))
my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a, b) = op(f(a),f(b))
my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a) = f(a)```

elements.text:
my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a, b, c, rest...) = my_mapeduce(f, op, a, my_mapreduce(f, op, b, c, rest...))
my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a, b) = op(f(a),f(b))
my_mapreduce(f::Function, op::Function, a) = f(a)

messages.text: you mean that?

I don't think that's quite right, you end up applying `f` multiple times to the same elements, e.g.
```my_mapreduce(-, *, 1, 2, 3) # 6
mapreduce(-, *, [1, 2, 3])  # -6```

elements.text: I don't think that's quite right, you end up applying
multiple times to the same elements, e.g.

messages.text: you only want to map once

elements.text: you only want to map once

messages.text: so `my_mapreduce(f, op, a...) = reduce(op, map(f, a))`

elements.text: my_mapreduce(f, op, a...) = reduce(op, map(f, a))

I was not able to load the package (i.e. import DAMMmodel failed). See the CI logs for details.

and I am not sure what to do, on my REPL, these work perfectly fine:
```]activate .
import DAMMmodel```
then I can use my package normally.

Any idea of how I could troubleshoot this? I probably did something wrong!

messages.text:
Suppose I use an integer `id` parameter as a type instead of a attribute of  a struct, such that:
```struct Track{ID}
end```
instead of:
```struct Track
    id::Int
end```
Then, if I use the first approach, functions that receive a `Track` instance will be compiled for each `ID`, such that if I have millions tracks and loop over them:
```for track in tracks
    segmentize(track)
end```
`segmentize` will be compiled millions of times, right?

So I should use the first approach?

elements.text: parameter as a type instead of a attribute of  a struct, such that:

instance will be compiled for each
, such that if I have millions tracks and loop over them:

for track in tracks
    segmentize(track)
end

will be compiled millions of times, right?

So I should use the first approach?

messages.text:
I am using `Distributed` to run replicate simulations on multiple processes and running into some "world age" issues. Essentially, I have a `evolve_worker(input, output)` function that has parameter objects in the `input` channel and then saves the data in the `output` channel. The parameter objects have a mix of scalar parameter values and functions like
```struct Params
    val::Int
    func::Function
end```
I usually assign an anonymous function to the `func` field in `Params`.

When I run `for w in workers() remote_do(evolve_worker, w, input, output) end`, julia complains about the `MethodError: no method matching` and `applicable method may be too new` in the part of `evolve_worker` that uses `Params.func`.

Looking at <https://github.com/dfdx/Spark.jl/issues/78>, it seems like the solution is to invoke `Params.func` with `Base.invokelatest`. Is this right? Is there any better way of sending anonymous functions to distributed workers without running into world age issues?

. Is this right? Is there any better way of sending anonymous functions to distributed workers without running into world age issues?

messages.text:
```using ZMQ # v1.2.1
using ZMQ: libzmq

const threadid = zeros(Int, 128)

function heartbeat_thread(sock::Ptr{Cvoid})
    ccall((:zmq_proxy,libzmq), Cint, (Ptr{Cvoid}, Ptr{Cvoid}, Ptr{Cvoid}),
          sock, sock, C_NULL)
    nothing
end

const heartbeat = Ref{Socket}()
heartbeat[] = Socket(ROUTER)

sock = heartbeat[]

# function start_heartbeat(sock)
heartbeat_c = @cfunction(heartbeat_thread, Cvoid, (Ptr{Cvoid},))
ccall(:uv_thread_create, Cint, (Ptr{Int}, Ptr{Cvoid}, Ptr{Cvoid}), threadid, heartbeat_c, sock) # this line segfaults```
This segfaults on macOS and julia#master (or julia#release-1.6). It is fine on windows and ubuntu, irrespective of the used julia version, but also on macos when using 1.5.3. Should I file an issue at JuliaLang/julia? It came up here: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/IJulia.jl/issues/968#issuecomment-752961832>

elements.text:

          sock, sock, C_NULL)
    nothing
end

const heartbeat = Ref{Socket}()
heartbeat[] = Socket(ROUTER)

sock = heartbeat[]

# function start_heartbeat(sock)
heartbeat_c = @cfunction(heartbeat_thread, Cvoid, (Ptr{Cvoid},))
ccall(:uv_thread_create, Cint, (Ptr{Int}, Ptr{Cvoid}, Ptr{Cvoid}), threadid, heartbeat_c, sock) # this line segfaults

messages.text:
Hi, I want to group my array by the same ID, and I need to do it very fast, so I am trying this
```table = [(20,1),(30,2),(30,3),(40,4)]
function group_by(table)
    sort!(table, by=x->x[1])
    ranges = []
    prev_start = prev_stop = (table[1][1], 1)
    for (i,row) in enumerate(table[1:end])
        if row[1] > prev_stop[1]
            prev_start = prev_stop
            prev_stop = (row[1],i)
            push!(ranges,(prev_start[2],prev_stop[2]-1))
        end
    end
    return ranges
end
group_by(table)```
However, this drops last element, and I am having hard time understanding why... again 1-based indexing pain :disappointed: What am I doing wrong? Is this even the most efficient way of finding groups by first element of array of tuples ?

elements.text: Hi, I want to group my array by the same ID, and I need to do it very fast, so I am trying this

table = [(20,1),(30,2),(30,3),(40,4)]
function group_by(table)
    sort!(table, by=x->x[1])
    ranges = []
    prev_start = prev_stop = (table[1][1], 1)
    for (i,row) in enumerate(table[1:end])
        if row[1] > prev_stop[1]
            prev_start = prev_stop
            prev_stop = (row[1],i)
            push!(ranges,(prev_start[2],prev_stop[2]-1))
        end
    end
    return ranges
end
group_by(table)
However, this drops last element, and I am having hard time understanding why... again 1-based indexing pain
What am I doing wrong? Is this even the most efficient way of finding groups by first element of array of tuples ?

ranges = typeof((prev_start[2],prev_stop[2]-1))[]

messages.text:
Hi all!  I am trying to make a type that is a union type:
```AbstractWord{N} = Union{NTuple{N, T}, AbstractVector{T}} where {T}```
However, I want this method to work:
```getlength(::AbstractWord{N}) where {N} = N```
This will currently only work if the input is an `NTuple`, not a vector.  I am wondering how I might go about doing this for the vector as well?

messages.text:
Is there a more compact way to write
```function interp!(A, B, dim)
    Rpre = CartesianIndices(size(A)[1:dim-1])
    Rpost = CartesianIndices(size(A)[dim+1:end])
    n = size(A, dim)
    for Ipost in Rpost
        for i = 1:n
            for Ipre in Rpre
                A[Ipre, i, Ipost] = B[Ipre, i, Ipost]/2 + B[Ipre, i+1, Ipost]/2
            end
        end
    end
end```
? I was thinking something like
```function interp!(A, B, dim)
    for (Ipre, i, Ipost) in sweep(A, dim)
        A[Ipre, i, Ipost] = B[Ipre, i, Ipost]/2 + B[Ipre, i+1, Ipost]/2
    end
end```
This would require `sweep` to return something with `iterate` defined
for it, and somehow recover and pass `Ipre, i, Ipost` through.

I started trying to do this, but I'm having trouble recovering `Ipre, i, Ipost`.

elements.text: Is there a more compact way to write

    Rpost = CartesianIndices(size(A)[dim+1:end])

    for Ipost in Rpost
        for i = 1:n
            for Ipre in Rpre
                A[Ipre, i, Ipost] = B[Ipre, i, Ipost]/2 + B[Ipre, i+1, Ipost]/2
            end
        end
    end
end

messages.text: Can anybody help me with understanding `Transducers`? I'm trying to use `collect((1:3,2:4)|>Zip|>MapSplat(==))` to get `[0,0,0]` (i.e. I want to do an element wise binary operation on 2 iterators). However I get a really long error message that I don't really understand. Any ideas?

messages.text:
I am getting the error `syntax: too few type parameters specified in "new{...}" around …`, so I looked it up but the solution I found <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-resolve-syntax-too-few-type-parameters-specified-in-new/15766|here> doesn’t work.  This is the struct I am trying to make:
```mutable struct Word{N, T} <: AbstractWord{N, T}
    w::MVector{N, T}
    
    Word(w::NTuple{N, T}) where {N, T} = new{typeof(w)}(MVector{N, T}(w))
    Word(w::AbstractVector{T}) where {T} = new{typeof(w)}(MVector{length(w), T}(w))
end```
Does anyone know why I am still getting the error?

messages.text:
Why is the <https://github.com/FluxML/Flux.jl/blob/master/src/data/dataloader.jl#L3|dataloader >using `Int` and `Bool` in struct definition:
```struct DataLoader{D}
    data::D
    batchsize::Int
    nobs::Int
    partial::Bool
    imax::Int
    indices::Vector{Int}
    shuffle::Bool
end```
I thought the recommendation was to do:
```struct DataLoader{D, T<:Int, B<:Bool}
    data::D
    batchsize::T
    nobs::T
    partial::B
    imax::T
    indices::Vector{T}
    shuffle::B
end```
here: <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/performance-tips/#Type-declarations>

end

struct DataLoader{D, T<:Int, B<:Bool}
    data::D
    batchsize::T
    nobs::T
    partial::B
    imax::T
    indices::Vector{T}

end
